title: 104_hr1946
content: The Act may be cited as the "Parental Rights and Responsibilities Act of 1995". It includes findings and purposes. The Parental Rights and Responsibilities Act of 1995 recognizes the fundamental right of parents to direct the upbringing of their children, as established by the Supreme Court. The role of parents in raising their children is highly valued and deserving of protection by all levels of government. The tradition of western civilization recognizes parents' responsibility to love, nurture, train, and protect their children. Some courts have not treated parental rights as fundamental, leading to improper judicial review of government actions affecting these rights. Parents are facing increasing intrusions into their responsibilities. Parents are experiencing government interference in their decisions and actions without compelling justification, leading to conflicts in parenting philosophies. Judicial review is being applied to government conduct that impacts parental rights, emphasizing the need for courts to evaluate cases concerning parental rights. The Act aims to protect parents' right to raise their children and safeguard children from abuse and neglect, balancing the interests of parents, children, and government. The Act aims to protect parents' rights and responsibilities in educating their children, as specified by the Supreme Court in Wisconsin v. Yoder, while preserving parental choices in healthcare decisions for children. The Act aims to protect parental rights in education and healthcare decisions for children, with a standard of judicial review for parental rights and a 4-step process for evaluating cases. The Act aims to protect parental rights in education and healthcare decisions for children through a 4-step process to evaluate cases concerning parental rights. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "appropriate evidence" as probable cause for temporary actions and clear and convincing evidence for final actions or termination of parental custody/visitation. The term "child" is defined according to State law. The term "child" and "parent" are defined according to State law. The right of a parent to direct the upbringing of a child includes directing or providing for the education of the child. The Act defines the limited rights of a parent including education, healthcare decisions, discipline, and religious teaching of the child. No application to parental decisions on health. The Act defines the limited rights of a parent, including education, discipline, and religious teaching of the child. It does not include the right to make health care decisions that endanger the child's life or result in serious physical injury. The term "right of a parent to direct the upbringing of a child" does not include a right to act in a manner that constitutes abuse or neglect of a child. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, and each territory and possession of the United States. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION ON INTERFERING WITH OR USURPING RIGHTS OF PARENTS. No government official shall interfere with a parent's right to direct their child's upbringing. SEC. 5. STRICT SCRUTINY. Exceptions to parental rights can only be made if essential for a compelling government interest and done in the least restrictive way. SEC. 6. CLAIM OR DEFENSE. SEC. 6. CLAIM OR DEFENSE. Any parent can raise a violation of this Act in court or before an administrative tribunal as a claim or defense. SEC. 7. DOMESTIC RELATIONS CASES AND DISPUTES BETWEEN PARENTS. This Act does not apply to domestic relations cases or disputes between parents. SEC. 8. ATTORNEY'S FEES. SEC. 8. ATTORNEY'S FEES. Subsections (b) and (c) of section 722 of the Revised Statutes (42 U.S.C. 1988 (b) and (c)) apply to cases under this Act. A person using this Act to defend against a government suit is considered the plaintiff for fee award purposes.
